docs.snippet: MOSCOW, Oct. 8 -- In conversation with foreign correspondents, Andrei A. Gromyko re-emphasized last night that the Soviet Union no longer was insisting that an undertaking not to use atomic weapons should be the first step in international disarma...
docs.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Oct. 8 -- In conversation with foreign correspondents, Andrei A. Gromyko re-emphasized last night that the Soviet Union no longer was insisting that an undertaking not to use atomic weapons should be the first step in international disarmament.
docs.abstract: com debate due; Deputy Min Gromyko stresses USSR no longer insists on prior atomic weapons ban

headline.main: GROMYKO GIVES ATOM TALK; Stresses Changed Soviet View on Nuclear Weapons Ban

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON Because of a change in State Department travel restrictions, American tourists are now free to visit Albania, one of the five Communist nations that have been generally off limits to United States citizens....
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON Because of a change in State Department travel restrictions, American tourists are now free to visit Albania, one of the five Communist nations that have been generally off limits to United States citizens.
docs.abstract: Comment on gradual easing of curbs; number of passports validated for travel to each banned nation noted

headline.main: More 'Freedom of Travel'; Lifting of Albanian Ban Reflects Reassertion Of U.S. Policy

docs.snippet: FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 24 -- The Czechoslovak Government has ordered its consulates to refrain, until further notice, from issuing any visas to persons desiring to enter Czechoslovakia, it was disclosed by Czechoslovak officials here...
docs.lead_paragraph: FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Feb. 24 -- The Czechoslovak Government has ordered its consulates to refrain, until further notice, from issuing any visas to persons desiring to enter Czechoslovakia, it was disclosed by Czechoslovak officials here today.
docs.abstract: Govt bans entrance visas to all foreigners

headline.main: Czechoslovakia Puts Ban on Entrance Visa; U.S. Army Cancels Holiday Tours There

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Aug. 8--The Isle of Man's elected representatives, in a Ruritanian scuffle with the British Government regarding pirate radio, decided today to appeal their grievances to the Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth....
docs.lead_paragraph: DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Aug. 8--The Isle of Man's elected representatives, in a Ruritanian scuffle with the British Government regarding pirate radio, decided today to appeal their grievances to the Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth.
docs.abstract: Manx House of Keys, 18-6, votes to appeal to Commonwealth Prime Mins against law forbidding commercial pirate radio stations; major issue is Radio Caroline, which has been beaming free commercials for tourism on island; map; Manx seek to increase power of own station if Radio Caroline is barred

headline.main: Isle of Man Fights British Radio Curb; ISLE OF MAN UPSET AT BAN ON RADIO

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that Representative Charles O. Porter, Democrat of Oregon, was not entitled to a passport to visit Communist China merely because he was a member of Congress....
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that Representative Charles O. Porter, Democrat of Oregon, was not entitled to a passport to visit Communist China merely because he was a member of Congress.
docs.abstract: Appeals Ct rules Repr Porter not entitled to passport to Communist China merely because he is Repr; might rule otherwise if visit were authorized by Cong com

headline.main: LEGISLATOR LOSES CHINA TRAVEL BID; Porter of Oregon Declared an Individual by Court Under Passport Ban

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Supreme Court ordered a Federal court in Mississippi today to uphold quickly the right of Negroes to unsegregated transportation service.
docs.abstract: Bailey et al v Patterson et al: Ct orders Fed ct, Miss, to uphold Negroes right to unsegregated transportation service; holds anti-segregation tenet has been estab in prior decisions

headline.main: Supreme Court Reaffirms Ban on Travel Segregation; COURT REAFFIRMS SEGREGATION BAN
